chapters.content:
Do not refer if emergency is not controlled!

Never refer a patient with uncontrolled bleeding, retained placenta, uncontrolled hypertension, unevacuated septic or haemorrhagic abortion or septic shock.

Remove placenta by trained provider.

In cases of prolonged labour:
- If at a peripheral facility, refer the woman to a higher centre with her partograph for further management.

- At a referral facility, amniotomy may be done (also for HIV+ women if on antiretroviral therapy). Reassess in 2 hours and decide on further management if there is insufficient progress.

After emergency management and when in a stable condition, discuss decision of referral with woman and relatives.

Quickly organise transport and possible financial aid.

Inform the referral center.

Accompany the woman.

It is crucial that she is accompanied by a health worker who is trained in delivery care and able to manage an emergency situation, if it recurrs during transport.

Consider to bring a relative who can donate blood.

Bring

Referral note.

Essential emergency drugs:

  • Oxytocin and Ergometrine (alternatively Misoprostol) for treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
  • Oxytocin for IM injection immediately postpartum
  • Hydralazine for IV treatment of elevated blood pressure
  • Magnesium Sulphate for eclampsia
  • Calcium Gluconate for intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate
  • Ampicillin for infections
  • Diazepam for pain relief

Supplies:

  • Delivery set
  • Towels
  • IV-equipment + IV fluids
  • Foetoscope or Doppler
  • Blood pressure monitor
  • Ambu bag
  • Suction bulb

During Transport

Observe vital signs and level of consciousness.

If pregnant check FHR.

In case of excessive vaginal bleeding apply bimanual compression.

If the bleeding does not stop apply aorta compression (can be maintained up to 6 hours).

If the woman’s condition permits:

Keep record of all IV fluids, medications given, time of administration and the woman´s condition.

If in labour during transport:

FHR every half an hour.

If pushing and superficial breathing is not enough to repress this urge, stop the transport and deliver the woman.

drugDetails.content:
Indications and Usage

For prophylaxis of ophthalmia neonatorum due to N. gonorrhoeae or C. trachomatis.

Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) including gonorrhea and chlamydia are a main cause of newborn eye infections (the newborn can get transmitted during delivery).

These infections can cause blindness if not treated.

Give antibiotic eye drops or ointment (e.g. Erythromycin Ophtalmic Ointment) to the newborn to prevent eye infections.

Dosage and Administration

For prophylaxis of neonatal gonococcal or chlamydial ophthalmia, a ribbon of ointment approximately 1 cm in length should be instilled into each lower conjunctival sac.

The ointment should not be flushed from the eye following instillation.

A new tube should be used for each infant.

For treatment of eye infection:

Do the following 6-8 times daily:

  • Wash hands with clean water and soap.
  • Wet clean cloth with boiled and cooled water.
  • Use the wet cloth to gently wash off pus from the baby’s eyes.
  • Apply 1% tetracycline eye ointment in each eye 3 times daily.
  • Wash hands.

Contraindications

None

Adverse Reactions

The most frequently reported adverse reactions are minor ocular irritations, redness and hypersensitivity reactions.

Indications and Usage

Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E1.

Misoprostol is indicated to produce uterine contractions during the third stage of labor and to control postpartum bleeding or haemorrhage.

Dosage and Administration

For preventing post partum haemorrhage:

600 micrograms (3 tablets) sublingually.

For treatment of post partum haemorrhage:

800 micrograms (4 tablets) sublingually.

Repeat 200-800 mcg.

Maximum dose: 1600 mcg.

Contraindications

Prostaglandin allergy. Prostaglandins should not be given to pregnant women as they cause abortion.

Adverse reactions

One out of three treated with misoprostol will have diarrhea or abdominal pain.

It is also common to see a non-allergic rash.

A few percent will experience a transient moderate increase in temperature.

Some will have nausea, vomiting, constipation or flatulence.

Less common headache and dizziness is experienced.

Rarely misoprostol can cause liver affection.

Indications and usage

Oxytocin is a pituitary gland hormone.

Oxytocin injection is indicated to produce uterine contractions during the third stage of labor and to control postpartum haemorrhage.

Dosage and administration

Prevention of postpartum haemorrhage (for all women who have delivered):

10 units (1 ml.) of Oxytocin given intramuscularly immediately after delivery of the baby.

Treatment of postpartum haemorrhage:

20 units of Oxytocin added to 1 litre intravenous fluid (normal saline or Ringer’s lactate) given at fastest flow rate possible.

Continuing IV. dose:

Infuse 20 units of Oxytocin in 1 L. IV. fluids at 40 drops per minute.

Maximum dose:

Not more than 3 L of IV fluids containing Oxytocin.

Oxytocin is temperature sensitive and loses effectiveness after three months of storage at temperatures higher than 30 degrees Celsius (86 degrees Fahrenheit).

Store Oxytocin at a temperature between 2 and 8°C.

Contraindications

Hypersensitivity to Oxytocin.

Do not give Oxytocin as an IV bolus.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are cardiac arrhythmia, nausea, and vomiting.

Rare complications are severe water intoxication which can lead to convulsions and coma and even death, anaphylactic reaction and the loss of clotting factors (fibrinogen) in the blood leading to bleeding complications.

Indications and Usage

Prevents bleeding complications in the newborn.

Dosage and Administration

1 mg given intramuscularly once, directly after birth, to all newborns.

Contraindications

None.

questions.question: Why should you actively manage the third stage of labour?

answers.value: To reduce the risk of postpartum haemorrhage
To reduce the risk of postpartum infections
To reduce the woman’s pain
To reduce the risk of postpartum seizures

questions.question: Which medicine should you prepare before every birth?

Oxytocin

answers.value: To make the mother relax
To stop the pulsation in the umbilical cord
To stimulate the uterus to contract
To help initiating the breastfeeding

questions.question: How much Oxytocin IM should you give to the mother after birth?
questions.description: You should give 10 IU Oxytocin IM to the mother after birth.

answers.value: 10 mg
10 IU

answers.value: Seconds before the foetus is born
Within one minute after birth of the newborn
Right after delivery of the placenta

questions.question: How should Oxytocin be stored?
questions.description:
Oxytocin should be stored:

Between 2 and 8 degrees Celsius.

answers.value: Between -5 and -2 degrees Celsius
Between 2 and 8 degrees Celsius
In a dark room at room temperature between 25-30 degrees Celsius

answers.value: Give 600 micrograms of Misoprostol
Give 800 micrograms of Misoprostol
Give 600 milligrams of Misoprostol
Since this is a preventive drug administration, no alternative is necessary

questions.question: How can Misoprostol be administered?
questions.description: Misoprostol can be administered sublingually/orally.

answers.value: I.M.
I.V.
Sublingually /orally

questions.question: When should you assess the newborn after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/newborn_on_the_mother
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description: You should assess the newborn immediately after birth.

answers.value: After the newborn has tried to breastfeed
Immediately after birth
It is only necessary to assess the newborn if it does not cry after birth

questions.question: A baby is born in thick meconium and is in need of resuscitation. Should you dry before you suction?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/green_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description: You dry the newborn, you clamp the cord, you suction and you ventilate.

answers.value: No
Yes

questions.question: How should you clear the baby’s airway when it is born with thick meconium?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/green_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description: You clear the baby’s airway when it is born with thick meconium by suctioning the meconium out of the mouth and nose.

answers.value: By suctioning the meconium out of the mouth and nose
By blowing in the baby’s mouth and nose
By drying the meconium away from the baby’s mouth and nose
Wait and see if the newborn can clear the airways itself by screaming – if not suction.

questions.question: What should you do with the newborn within 5 seconds after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/brand_new_baby
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description: Newborns have difficulties regulating their temperature and lose body heat quickly. Therefore, dry the newborn immediately with a dry towel, put on a hat and cover the baby when lying on the mother’s chest.

answers.value: Clamp and cut the umbilical cord
Place the newborn on the weighing scale
Dry the baby with a dry towel and stimulate by rubbing the back
Dry the baby with a wet, hot towel and put it at the mother’s breast

questions.question: How should you keep the baby warm?

questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn

answers.value: Remove wet towels and cover with dry cloth after assessing the baby
Cover with dry cloth without assessing the baby
Cover with wet towels as this is good for the baby’s skin

questions.question: When should you start neonatal bag and mask ventilation?

answers.value: If crying loudly and moving the chest quickly
If heart rate is above 100 beats per minutes
If not crying well or not breathing 30 seconds after birth despite stimulation

questions.question: How do you know if the newborn is stable so you can proceed to routine initial care?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/dry_newborn
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/assess_the_newborn
questions.description:
You know that the newborn is stable so you can proceed to routine initial care:

If it is crying and breathing well with good colour.

If it is moving its arms and legs with a good tone.

If it has a heart rate above 100 beats per minute.

answers.value: If it is crying and breathing well with good colour
If it is moving its arms and legs with a good tone
If it has a heart rate above 100 beats per minute
If it has a heart rate above 60 beats per minute

questions.question: When should you clamp and cut the umbilical cord of a well looking newborn?

answers.value: Immediately after birth
1-3 minutes after birth or when the cord stops pulsating
10 minutes after birth
Before the cord stops pulsating

questions.question: How should you start the delivery of placenta?

questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: You start the delivery of the placenta by holding the cord tight and pulling it very gently parallel to the surface of the delivery bed during a contraction while the other hand pushes the uterus in the other direction.

answers.value: By holding the cord tight and pulling it very gently parallel to the surface of the delivery bed during a contraction while the other hand pushes the uterus in the other direction
There is no need to assist the delivery of the placenta
By holding the cord tight and pulling it very gently parallel to the surface of the delivery bed in between contractions while the other hand pushes the uterus in the other direction

questions.question: You hold the cord tight with one hand when delivering the placenta. What should you do with the other hand?

questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: With the other hand you apply counter pressure above the pubic bone.

answers.value: Apply counter pressure at perineum
Apply counter pressure above the pubic bone
Apply counter pressure at the top of the uterus

questions.question: What normally happens to the uterus and cord after 2-3 minutes of holding the cord tightly as a sign of a detached placenta?

questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: Normally after 2-3 minutes of holding the cord tightly as a sign of a detached placenta the uterus becomes rounded and the cord lengthens.

answers.value: The uterus becomes rounded and the cord lengthens
The uterus will expand and the cord shortens

questions.question: How can the mother cooperate with the delivery of placenta?

Crucial parts of an examination of the placenta are:

Make sure no tissue is missing on the maternal surface

Measure the length of the umbilical cord

That it is breastfeeding well
Tone and heart rate

questions.question: What should you give the newborn after birth?

questions.question: Why is early breastfeeding important for the newborn?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/breastfeeding
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description:
Early breastfeeding is important for the newborn because:

It helps the newborn to fully inflate the lungs.

It provides important nutrition to the newborn.

It strengthens the newborn’s immune system.

answers.value: It helps the newborn to fully inflate the lungs
It provides important nutrition to the newborn
It prepares the newborn for bottle feeding
It strengthens the newborn’s immune system

questions.question: Why is early breastfeeding important for the mother?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/breastfeeding
questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/monitoring
questions.description: Early breastfeeding important for the mother because it stimulates the uterus to contract.

answers.value: It stimulates the uterus to contract

It protects her from getting pregnant again

questions.question: How do you deliver the membranes following the placenta in the best way?

questions.link: video:/Active management of third stage labour/controlled_cord_traction
questions.description: You deliver the membranes following the placenta in the best way by continuously rotating the placenta, so the membranes become like a rope.

chapters.content:
1. Pushing for more than one hour with good contractions.
  2. Foetal heart rate remaining below 100 or above 180 beats per minute.
  3. Maternal exhaustion.
  4. Maternal heart disease or hypertension (though these patients should be giving birth in a referral facility).

1. Cephalic presentation not more than 1/5 palpable above pubic bone.
  2. Position occiput posterior or occiput anterior.
  3. Fully dilated.
  4. Ruptured membranes.
  5. Relevant expertise.
  6. Willingness to stop.

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for. Go through A-J

Ask for help.

Address the patient, tell her what you are about to do while you continue to prepare, tell her that you need her to cooperate and keep pushing when there is a contraction.

Abdominal palpation – the head should not be palpable more than 1/5 above the pubic bone

Bladder empty.

Check that Cervix is fully dilated.

Contractions – there must be contractions to succeed.

Determine position – locate the posterior fontanel (triangular shaped) with your index finger. This is important to place the cup correctly.

Equipment ready – delivery tray, Oxytocin 10 IU for IM injection to the mother, towels, neonatal resuscitator, and vacuum extractor.

Flexion Point – most cups are 3 cm from the center to the edge. Place the edge of the cup at the tip of the posterior triangular fontanel.

Feel for vaginal tissue between the cup and the foetal skull before and after applying suction to avoid trauma to the vagina.

Gentle, steady traction with no rocking during a contraction; with the first contractions downward. During the following contractions, more upward.

Halt in between contractions.

HALT and abandon if three pop-offs, or if three pulls with no progress, or if 20 minutes from application delivery is not achieved.

Intact perineum!

When the head is delivered during the next contraction protect perineum with one hand; squeeze the index and thumb together at the posterior part of the head to prevent stretching of the perineum and lift the head with your third finger upwards and away from the perineum, while the other hand keeps the head from coming too fast. An incision is only rarely needed.

Jaw reachable – release the vacuum and remove the cup.

Do not refer if emergency is not controlled!

Never refer a patient with uncontrolled bleeding, retained placenta, uncontrolled hypertension, unevacuated septic or haemorrhagic abortion or septic shock.

Remove placenta by trained provider.

In cases of prolonged labour:
- If at a peripheral facility, refer the woman to a higher centre with her partograph for further management.

- At a referral facility, amniotomy may be done (also for HIV+ women if on antiretroviral therapy). Reassess in 2 hours and decide on further management if there is insufficient progress.

After emergency management and when in a stable condition, discuss decision of referral with woman and relatives.

Quickly organise transport and possible financial aid.

Inform the referral center.

Accompany the woman.

It is crucial that she is accompanied by a health worker who is trained in delivery care and able to manage an emergency situation, if it recurrs during transport.

Consider to bring a relative who can donate blood.

Bring

Referral note.

Essential emergency drugs:

  • Oxytocin and Ergometrine (alternatively Misoprostol) for treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
  • Oxytocin for IM injection immediately postpartum
  • Hydralazine for IV treatment of elevated blood pressure
  • Magnesium Sulphate for eclampsia
  • Calcium Gluconate for intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate
  • Ampicillin for infections
  • Diazepam for pain relief

Supplies:

  • Delivery set
  • Towels
  • IV-equipment + IV fluids
  • Foetoscope or Doppler
  • Blood pressure monitor
  • Ambu bag
  • Suction bulb

During Transport

Observe vital signs and level of consciousness.

If pregnant check FHR.

In case of excessive vaginal bleeding apply bimanual compression.

If the bleeding does not stop apply aorta compression (can be maintained up to 6 hours).

If the woman’s condition permits:

Keep record of all IV fluids, medications given, time of administration and the woman´s condition.

If in labour during transport:

FHR every half an hour.

If pushing and superficial breathing is not enough to repress this urge, stop the transport and deliver the woman.

drugDetails.content:
Indications and Usage

Ampicillin is a B-lactamantibiotics effective on gram positive as well as negative bacterial infections.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

1 g intravenously every 6 hours (at sepsis initially each 4 hours).

Children:

First week of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 12 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Week 2-4 of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 8 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Contraindications

Allergy to penicillin.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are diarrhea and skin rash.

Uncommon reactions are nausea, vomiting, stomatitis, glossitis, pseudomembraneous colitis, lowered platelets, anemia and urticaria.

Anaphylactic shock is rare.

Indications and Usage

Diazepam is a benzodiazepine.

Diazepam is used to treat anxiety, agitation and convulsions.

Can also be used as analgesia before a painful procedure.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

Before procedure:

10 mg IV OR

10-20 mg IM OR

20 mg rectally OR

Second dose:

10 mg IV/IM/rectally

Children:

For convulsions:

give 0.5 mg/kg rectally once.

If convulsions persist after 10 minutes repeat 0.5mg/kg rectally one more time.

If convulsions persists after additional 10 min give 0.4 mg/kg intravenously maximum once.

If convulsions occur in early pregnancy or if Magnesium Sulphate toxicity occurs or Magnesium Sulphate is not available.

Loading dose IV:

Give Diazepam 10 mg IV slowly over 2 minutes.

If convulsions recur, repeat 10 mg.

Maintenace dose:

Give Diazepam 40 mg in 500 ml IV fluids (normal saline or Ringer’s lactate) titrated over 6-8 hours to keep the woman sedated but rousable.

Stop the maintenance dose if breathing is affected.

Assist ventilation if necessary with mask and bag.

Do not give more than 100 mg in 24 hours.

If IV access is not possible (e.g. during convulsion), give Diazepam rectally.

Loading dose rectally:

Give 20 mg (4 ml) in a 10 ml syringe (or urinary catheter):

Remove the needle, lubricate the barrel and insert the syringe into the rectum to half its length.

Discharge the contents and leave the syringe in place, holding the buttocks together for 10 minutes to prevent expulsion of the drug.

If convulsions recur, repeat 10 mg.

Maintenance dose:

Give additional 10 mg (2 ml) every hour during transport.

Contraindications

Alcohol intoxication.

Severe respiratory or liver illness.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are drowsiness and confusion.

Uncommon reactions are muscle weakness, coordination difficulties, headache, concentration difficulty and dizziness.

Rare reactions are respiratory depression or respiratory stop, aggression, hallucinations, psychosis, and allergic reactions.

Diazepam should not be used long term as tolerance and addiction occurs commonly.

Indications and Usage

Ergometrine is a semisynthetic ergot alkaloid.

Ergometrine is used to treat post partum haemorrhage.

Dosage and Administration

0.2 mg. or 0.5 mg. (one vial) intravenously (most reliable and fastest) or intramuscularly.

Can be repeated after 15 minutes if heavy bleeding persists.

Maximum dose:

Not more than five doses of Ergometrine 0.2 mg. or two doses of Ergometrine 0.5 mg.

Contraindications

High blood pressure (above 140/90 mm Hg), including preeclampsia.

Heart disease.

Retained placenta.

Allergy to ergotalkaloids.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are hypertension, headache, non allergic skin rash and lower abdominal pain.

Less common are nausea and vomiting, dizziness, chest pains and increased sweating.

Rare adverse reactions are bradycardia, tachycardia, myocardial infarction, hallucinations and tinnitus.

Indications and Usage

For prevention and treatment of anemia caused by iron deficiency and bleeding.

Dosage and Administration

Prevention of iron deficiency during pregnancy:

30-60 mg in combination with Folic Acid 400 micrograms daily.

During treatment of anemia caused by iron deficiency and bleeding:

120 mg. twice a day for 3 months.

Contraindications

Hemosiderosis and hemochromatosis.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are nausea, abdominal pains, diarrhea and constipation.

Stool becomes black though the color is “dusty” rather than glossy (as seen at gastrointestinal bleeding).

Indications and Usage

Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E1.

Misoprostol is indicated to produce uterine contractions during the third stage of labor and to control postpartum bleeding or haemorrhage.

Dosage and Administration

For preventing post partum haemorrhage:

600 micrograms (3 tablets) sublingually.

For treatment of post partum haemorrhage:

800 micrograms (4 tablets) sublingually.

Repeat 200-800 mcg.

Maximum dose: 1600 mcg.

Contraindications

Prostaglandin allergy. Prostaglandins should not be given to pregnant women as they cause abortion.

Adverse reactions

One out of three treated with misoprostol will have diarrhea or abdominal pain.

It is also common to see a non-allergic rash.

A few percent will experience a transient moderate increase in temperature.

Some will have nausea, vomiting, constipation or flatulence.

Less common headache and dizziness is experienced.

Rarely misoprostol can cause liver affection.

Indications and usage

Strong opioid analgetic drug.

Dosage and administration

5-10 mg intramuscularly.

2.5-5 mg intravenously.

Can be repeated if insufficient response after 30 minutes up to a maximum dose of 60 mg over 24 hours.

Contraindications

History of severe reactions to opioids (respiratory stop).

Severe respiratory insufficiency, paralytic ileus, liver insufficiency.

Should not be given in first trimester.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are nausea, vomiting, euphoria, drowsiness, dizziness, fainting and mood disturbances.

Uncommon reactions are agitation, trembling, confusion, fits, urticaria, respiratory depression, increased or decreased pulse and constipation.

Rare reactions are hallucinations, itching, skin rash and anaphylactic reactions.

Indications and usage

Oxytocin is a pituitary gland hormone.

Oxytocin injection is indicated to produce uterine contractions during the third stage of labor and to control postpartum haemorrhage.

Dosage and administration

Prevention of postpartum haemorrhage (for all women who have delivered):

10 units (1 ml.) of Oxytocin given intramuscularly immediately after delivery of the baby.

Treatment of postpartum haemorrhage:

20 units of Oxytocin added to 1 litre intravenous fluid (normal saline or Ringer’s lactate) given at fastest flow rate possible.

Continuing IV. dose:

Infuse 20 units of Oxytocin in 1 L. IV. fluids at 40 drops per minute.

Maximum dose:

Not more than 3 L of IV fluids containing Oxytocin.

Oxytocin is temperature sensitive and loses effectiveness after three months of storage at temperatures higher than 30 degrees Celsius (86 degrees Fahrenheit).

Store Oxytocin at a temperature between 2 and 8°C.

Contraindications

Hypersensitivity to Oxytocin.

Do not give Oxytocin as an IV bolus.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are cardiac arrhythmia, nausea, and vomiting.

Rare complications are severe water intoxication which can lead to convulsions and coma and even death, anaphylactic reaction and the loss of clotting factors (fibrinogen) in the blood leading to bleeding complications.

chapters.content:
Emptying the bladder with a urine catheter is indicated:

  1. If a woman in labour fails to urinate spontaneously and the progress of labour is dissatisfactory, OR
  2. In cases of post partum haemorrhage, AND
  3. In any severely ill patient with for example sepsis or severe preeclampsia to monitor the urine output. In this case, the catheter should stay in place until the condition improves.

The urine should be clear, if not, there is a urine tract infection and antibiotics should be administered.

All patients in a critical state (sepsis, severe preeclampsia, eclampsia, bleeding, shock) must have a permanent catheter, and the hourly urine output should be at least 30 millilitres.

If less, the underlying cause should be treated and fluid replacement considered, although not more than one litre over 8 hours for preeclampsia as the risk of fluid overload and pulmonary oedema is increased.

Before applying a permanent catheter, the area around the urethra should be cleaned twice with gauze swabs and normal saline water.

Measurement of the foetal heart rate in childbirth is indicated:

1) On admission,

2) During the 1st stage of delivery:

Every 30 minutes among mothers and babies at low risk, and every 15 minutes if any risk is identified for the mother or foetus, and

3) Immediately after every contraction and at least every five minutes in the 2nd stage of delivery.

The lower limit for a normal foetal heart rate is defined as 110 beats per minute (bpm).

A heart rate below 100 bpm indicates foetal asphyxia and immediate delivery is necessary.

The upper limit for a normal heart rate is 160 bpm.

A heart rate above 180 bpm indicates foetal asphyxia and immediate delivery is necessary.

The foetal heart is best heard by placing the foetoscope over the back of the baby.

Always measure the foetal heart rate for one minute immediately after a contraction (you will need a watch).

Measuring the maternal pulse and the foetal heart rate simultaneously can exclude a mix-up between the two.

Vacuum delivery is a “signal function” of basic emergency obstetric care, and so must be mastered by all skilled birth attendants.

When maternal efforts (pushing) fail or when there is a pathologic foetal heart rate in second stage of labour assisted vaginal delivery is indicated given the head is well engaged.

The major indications for the use of assisted vaginal delivery in the second stage of labour are:

prolonged second stage (over one hour of active pushing), maternal indications (maternal exhaustion), maternal medical illness (cardiac disease, hypertensive disorder) or non-reassuring foetal heart rate.

Prerequisites to instrument delivery are:

Vertex presentation, engagement in the pelvis (1/5), complete dilation of the cervix, rupture of membranes, empty bladder, no suspected true cephalopelvic disproportion, and willingness to stop the procedure if it does not go well.

Different types of vacuum extractors exist.

Most frequently used are the ones with metal or silicon cups and the hand-pump suction devices with a plastic cup.

Both can be used safely, the hand-pump devices have the benefit of the practitioner being in control for creating the vacuum, whilst with the other device an assistant is needed to operate the pump.

Metal and plastic cups are less likely to “pop off” and therefore the risk of failure is only half compared to the soft silicon cups.

Procedure

With the suction off, the center of the cup should be applied 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanel in the midline along the sagittal suture, the so-called the Flexion point.

The flexion point is an important point in maximizing traction and minimizing detachment of the cup.

As most cups have a diameter of 5 to 7 cm the edge of the cup will be over the posterior fontanel.

No maternal tissue, including the vagina, should be under the cup.

The risk of subgaleal haemorrhage increases if the cup edge is placed on the sagittal suture.

Improper application appears to be common with attempted vacuum assisted delivery and is thought to be a primary factor in unsuccessful attempts.

The vertex is wiped clean of blood and fluid.

The labia are spread, and the cup is gently inserted.

A finger is swept around the cup to make sure no maternal tissue is trapped beneath the cup.

Then vacuum is applied.

For the whole procedure, go through the A-J Mnemonic: Action Card > Vacuum Extraction

Complications

A vacuum assisted delivery is not a procedure without any risks, and should therefore be used when indications and prerequisites exist.

Proper application of vacuum is essential.

Both mother and infant should be examined for birth trauma after its application.

Traction can speed up delivery in emergency situations only when there is cooperation from the patient with pushing.

Proper traction at right angles to the plane of the vacuum cup, and in the axis of traction, is necessary to avoid losing the vacuum.

One type of complication of vacuum delivery is subgaleal hematoma, on rare occasions it may be life threatening.

This occurs when emissary veins are damaged and blood accumulates in the potential space between the galea aponeurotica and the periosteum of the skull.

Signs of subgaleal hematomas include diffuse swelling of the head that may shift dependently when the infant’s head is repositioned.

This swelling indents easily on palpation and may be significant enough to result in hypovolemic shock.

It is treated with a pressure bandage and replacement of volume if needed.

Subgaleal hematoma is quite different than a cephalohematoma, which is a collection of blood that accumulates under the periosteum of a skull bone (usually the parietal) and is characteristically limited to the confines of the cranial bone and therefore the amount of bleeding will not become dangerous.

Intracranial haemorrhage is a rare complication that may be life threatening, the risk is higher in the severe premature baby, therefore vacuum extraction should ideally not be applied before 36 weeks of gestation.

Vacuum delivery also increases the risk of maternal trauma, so the procedure should be performed only on a well established indication and assess carefully any trauma to the birth canal especially the anal sphincter by performing a rectal digital exploration.

Intravenous access is used to administer fluids and drugs.

Equipment for intravenous/intramuscular access should be located in the delivery room.

It should be available at all health facilities for adults as well as children.

It includes:

Antiseptic solution to clean the surrounding skin, syringes, intravenous cannulas, venflons, a stasis hose/band, tapes and cannulas.

Adults:

The grey and green cannulas have a large diameter.

Using them makes the fluid enter the body more rapidly.

Children:

For insertion of an intravenous cannula in the neonate select a suitable vein to place the cannula or a gauge 21 or 23 butterfly needle.

Peripheral vein:

  • Identify an accessible peripheral vein, see illustration.
  • An assistant should keep the position of the limb steady and should act as a tourniquet by obstructing the venous return with his or her fingers lightly closed around the limb. Alternatively use a stasis hose/band.
  • Clean the surrounding skin with an antiseptic solution (such as spirit, iodine, isopropyl alcohol or 7+ % alcohol solution), then introduce the cannula into the vein and insert most of its length. Fix the catheter securely with tape. Apply a splint with the limb in an appropriate position (e.g. elbow extended, wrist slightly flexed).

Scalp Vein:

These are often used in children ages less than 2 years but are most suitable in young infants.

  • Find a suitable scalp vein (usually in the midline of the forehead, the temporal area or above or behind the ear).
  • Shave the area if necessary, and clean the skin with an antiseptic solution. The assistant should occlude the vein proximal to the site of puncture. Fill a syringe and leave the end of the tubing open. Introduce the butterfly needle as described above. Blood flowing back slowly through the tubing indicates that the needle is in the vein.
  • Care should be taken not to cannulate an artery, which is recognised by palpation. If there is a pulsatile spurting of blood, withdraw the needle and apply pressure until the bleeding stops; then look for the vein.

chapters.content:
This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for. Start Here – Call For Help!

While you wait for helpers do the following:

  • Continuous uterus massage
  • Catheterise bladder
  • If strong bleeding persists – apply bimanual compression or aorta compression

When helpers arrive:

  • Co-ordinate:
  • Helper 1 at ‘head’
  • Helpers 2 and 3 at ‘arms’
  • Review other causes - 4 T’s
  1. Tone
  2. Trauma
  3. Tissue
  4. Thrombin

• Check airway and breathing
  • Ventilate if breathing is insufficient
  • Lie flat
  • Note time of relevant events
  • Reassure woman

This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for.
  • Check pulse and blood pressure
  • Large bore IV Access x2
  • X-match Blood
  • Start fluid resuscitation 3 L normal saline or Ringer’s lactate fast!
  • Give drugs:
    As per Government of India's guidelines:
  1. Start with Oxytocin drip. Blend 20 IU of Oxytocin in 1 L normal saline or Ringer's lactate and administer at 40-60 drops/ minute.
  2. If the bleeding continues, Ergometrine 0.2 mg. IV (contraindicated at hypertension and retained placenta).
  3. Misoprostol 800 mcg sublingually if the bleeding continues and Oxytocin is not available.

Do not refer if emergency is not controlled!

Never refer a patient with uncontrolled bleeding, retained placenta, uncontrolled hypertension, unevacuated septic or haemorrhagic abortion or septic shock.

Remove placenta by trained provider.

In cases of prolonged labour:
- If at a peripheral facility, refer the woman to a higher centre with her partograph for further management.

- At a referral facility, amniotomy may be done (also for HIV+ women if on antiretroviral therapy). Reassess in 2 hours and decide on further management if there is insufficient progress.

After emergency management and when in a stable condition, discuss decision of referral with woman and relatives.

Quickly organise transport and possible financial aid.

Inform the referral center.

Accompany the woman.

It is crucial that she is accompanied by a health worker who is trained in delivery care and able to manage an emergency situation, if it recurrs during transport.

Consider to bring a relative who can donate blood.

Bring

Referral note.

Essential emergency drugs:

  • Oxytocin and Ergometrine (alternatively Misoprostol) for treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
  • Oxytocin for IM injection immediately postpartum
  • Hydralazine for IV treatment of elevated blood pressure
  • Magnesium Sulphate for eclampsia
  • Calcium Gluconate for intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate
  • Ampicillin for infections
  • Diazepam for pain relief

Supplies:

  • Delivery set
  • Towels
  • IV-equipment + IV fluids
  • Foetoscope or Doppler
  • Blood pressure monitor
  • Ambu bag
  • Suction bulb

During Transport

Observe vital signs and level of consciousness.

If pregnant check FHR.

In case of excessive vaginal bleeding apply bimanual compression.

If the bleeding does not stop apply aorta compression (can be maintained up to 6 hours).

If the woman’s condition permits:

Keep record of all IV fluids, medications given, time of administration and the woman´s condition.

If in labour during transport:

FHR every half an hour.

If pushing and superficial breathing is not enough to repress this urge, stop the transport and deliver the woman.

drugDetails.content:
Indications and usage

Oxytocin is a pituitary gland hormone.

Oxytocin injection is indicated to produce uterine contractions during the third stage of labor and to control postpartum haemorrhage.

Dosage and administration

Prevention of postpartum haemorrhage (for all women who have delivered):

10 units (1 ml.) of Oxytocin given intramuscularly immediately after delivery of the baby.

Treatment of postpartum haemorrhage:

20 units of Oxytocin added to 1 litre intravenous fluid (normal saline or Ringer’s lactate) given at fastest flow rate possible.

Continuing IV. dose:

Infuse 20 units of Oxytocin in 1 L. IV. fluids at 40 drops per minute.

Maximum dose:

Not more than 3 L of IV fluids containing Oxytocin.

Oxytocin is temperature sensitive and loses effectiveness after three months of storage at temperatures higher than 30 degrees Celsius (86 degrees Fahrenheit).

Store Oxytocin at a temperature between 2 and 8°C.

Contraindications

Hypersensitivity to Oxytocin.

Do not give Oxytocin as an IV bolus.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are cardiac arrhythmia, nausea, and vomiting.

Rare complications are severe water intoxication which can lead to convulsions and coma and even death, anaphylactic reaction and the loss of clotting factors (fibrinogen) in the blood leading to bleeding complications.

Indications and Usage

Ergometrine is a semisynthetic ergot alkaloid.

Ergometrine is used to treat post partum haemorrhage.

Dosage and Administration

0.2 mg. or 0.5 mg. (one vial) intravenously (most reliable and fastest) or intramuscularly.

Can be repeated after 15 minutes if heavy bleeding persists.

Maximum dose:

Not more than five doses of Ergometrine 0.2 mg. or two doses of Ergometrine 0.5 mg.

Contraindications

High blood pressure (above 140/90 mm Hg), including preeclampsia.

Heart disease.

Retained placenta.

Allergy to ergotalkaloids.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are hypertension, headache, non allergic skin rash and lower abdominal pain.

Less common are nausea and vomiting, dizziness, chest pains and increased sweating.

Rare adverse reactions are bradycardia, tachycardia, myocardial infarction, hallucinations and tinnitus.

Indications and Usage

Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E1.

Misoprostol is indicated to produce uterine contractions during the third stage of labor and to control postpartum bleeding or haemorrhage.

Dosage and Administration

For preventing post partum haemorrhage:

600 micrograms (3 tablets) sublingually.

For treatment of post partum haemorrhage:

800 micrograms (4 tablets) sublingually.

Repeat 200-800 mcg.

Maximum dose: 1600 mcg.

Contraindications

Prostaglandin allergy. Prostaglandins should not be given to pregnant women as they cause abortion.

Adverse reactions

One out of three treated with misoprostol will have diarrhea or abdominal pain.

It is also common to see a non-allergic rash.

A few percent will experience a transient moderate increase in temperature.

Some will have nausea, vomiting, constipation or flatulence.

Less common headache and dizziness is experienced.

Rarely misoprostol can cause liver affection.

Indications and usage

Strong opioid analgetic drug.

Dosage and administration

5-10 mg intramuscularly.

2.5-5 mg intravenously.

Can be repeated if insufficient response after 30 minutes up to a maximum dose of 60 mg over 24 hours.

Contraindications

History of severe reactions to opioids (respiratory stop).

Severe respiratory insufficiency, paralytic ileus, liver insufficiency.

Should not be given in first trimester.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are nausea, vomiting, euphoria, drowsiness, dizziness, fainting and mood disturbances.

Uncommon reactions are agitation, trembling, confusion, fits, urticaria, respiratory depression, increased or decreased pulse and constipation.

Rare reactions are hallucinations, itching, skin rash and anaphylactic reactions.

Indications and Usage

Diazepam is a benzodiazepine.

Diazepam is used to treat anxiety, agitation and convulsions.

Can also be used as analgesia before a painful procedure.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

Before procedure:

10 mg IV OR

10-20 mg IM OR

20 mg rectally OR

Second dose:

10 mg IV/IM/rectally

Children:

For convulsions:

give 0.5 mg/kg rectally once.

If convulsions persist after 10 minutes repeat 0.5mg/kg rectally one more time.

If convulsions persists after additional 10 min give 0.4 mg/kg intravenously maximum once.

If convulsions occur in early pregnancy or if Magnesium Sulphate toxicity occurs or Magnesium Sulphate is not available.

Loading dose IV:

Give Diazepam 10 mg IV slowly over 2 minutes.

If convulsions recur, repeat 10 mg.

Maintenace dose:

Give Diazepam 40 mg in 500 ml IV fluids (normal saline or Ringer’s lactate) titrated over 6-8 hours to keep the woman sedated but rousable.

Stop the maintenance dose if breathing is affected.

Assist ventilation if necessary with mask and bag.

Do not give more than 100 mg in 24 hours.

If IV access is not possible (e.g. during convulsion), give Diazepam rectally.

Loading dose rectally:

Give 20 mg (4 ml) in a 10 ml syringe (or urinary catheter):

Remove the needle, lubricate the barrel and insert the syringe into the rectum to half its length.

Discharge the contents and leave the syringe in place, holding the buttocks together for 10 minutes to prevent expulsion of the drug.

If convulsions recur, repeat 10 mg.

Maintenance dose:

Give additional 10 mg (2 ml) every hour during transport.

Contraindications

Alcohol intoxication.

Severe respiratory or liver illness.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are drowsiness and confusion.

Uncommon reactions are muscle weakness, coordination difficulties, headache, concentration difficulty and dizziness.

Rare reactions are respiratory depression or respiratory stop, aggression, hallucinations, psychosis, and allergic reactions.

Diazepam should not be used long term as tolerance and addiction occurs commonly.

Indications and Usage

Ampicillin is a B-lactamantibiotics effective on gram positive as well as negative bacterial infections.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

1 g intravenously every 6 hours (at sepsis initially each 4 hours).

Children:

First week of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 12 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Week 2-4 of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 8 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Contraindications

Allergy to penicillin.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are diarrhea and skin rash.

Uncommon reactions are nausea, vomiting, stomatitis, glossitis, pseudomembraneous colitis, lowered platelets, anemia and urticaria.

Anaphylactic shock is rare.

Indications and Usage

For prevention and treatment of anemia caused by iron deficiency and bleeding.

Dosage and Administration

Prevention of iron deficiency during pregnancy:

30-60 mg in combination with Folic Acid 400 micrograms daily.

During treatment of anemia caused by iron deficiency and bleeding:

120 mg. twice a day for 3 months.

Contraindications

Hemosiderosis and hemochromatosis.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are nausea, abdominal pains, diarrhea and constipation.

Stool becomes black though the color is “dusty” rather than glossy (as seen at gastrointestinal bleeding).

chapters.content:
Emptying the bladder with a urine catheter is indicated:

  1. If a woman in labour fails to urinate spontaneously and the progress of labour is dissatisfactory, OR
  2. In cases of post partum haemorrhage, AND
  3. In any severely ill patient with for example sepsis or severe preeclampsia to monitor the urine output. In this case, the catheter should stay in place until the condition improves.

The urine should be clear, if not, there is a urine tract infection and antibiotics should be administered.

All patients in a critical state (sepsis, severe preeclampsia, eclampsia, bleeding, shock) must have a permanent catheter, and the hourly urine output should be at least 30 millilitres.

If less, the underlying cause should be treated and fluid replacement considered, although not more than one litre over 8 hours for preeclampsia as the risk of fluid overload and pulmonary oedema is increased.

Before applying a permanent catheter, the area around the urethra should be cleaned twice with gauze swabs and normal saline water.

Intravenous access is used to administer fluids and drugs.

Equipment for intravenous/intramuscular access should be located in the delivery room.

It should be available at all health facilities for adults as well as children.

It includes:

Antiseptic solution to clean the surrounding skin, syringes, intravenous cannulas, venflons, a stasis hose/band, tapes and cannulas.

Adults:

The grey and green cannulas have a large diameter.

Using them makes the fluid enter the body more rapidly.

Children:

For insertion of an intravenous cannula in the neonate select a suitable vein to place the cannula or a gauge 21 or 23 butterfly needle.

Peripheral vein:

  • Identify an accessible peripheral vein, see illustration.
  • An assistant should keep the position of the limb steady and should act as a tourniquet by obstructing the venous return with his or her fingers lightly closed around the limb. Alternatively use a stasis hose/band.
  • Clean the surrounding skin with an antiseptic solution (such as spirit, iodine, isopropyl alcohol or 7+ % alcohol solution), then introduce the cannula into the vein and insert most of its length. Fix the catheter securely with tape. Apply a splint with the limb in an appropriate position (e.g. elbow extended, wrist slightly flexed).

Scalp Vein:

These are often used in children ages less than 2 years but are most suitable in young infants.

  • Find a suitable scalp vein (usually in the midline of the forehead, the temporal area or above or behind the ear).
  • Shave the area if necessary, and clean the skin with an antiseptic solution. The assistant should occlude the vein proximal to the site of puncture. Fill a syringe and leave the end of the tubing open. Introduce the butterfly needle as described above. Blood flowing back slowly through the tubing indicates that the needle is in the vein.
  • Care should be taken not to cannulate an artery, which is recognised by palpation. If there is a pulsatile spurting of blood, withdraw the needle and apply pressure until the bleeding stops; then look for the vein.

CBT content courtesy of Dr. Staffan Bergström.

Indication

Condom tamponade technique is indicated when there is profuse uterine bleeding un-stoppable by AMTSL as an attempt to prevent hysterectomy.

Tools

  • Sterile cloth
  • IV-fluids of any kind
  • Sterile gloves
  • Sterile condom
  • IV fluid set (remove the outermost tip of it so there is a little knob)
  • Ligature
  • Clamp (non traumatic) - minimum 25 cm.
  • Headlight
  • Two (broad) specula - one down, one up

How to do it

Stop the bleeding by external compression of the aorta (See Manual Removal of Placenta video).

Keep the fist in position until the condom tamponade insertion has taken place.

When mounting the condom on the plastic tubing; be careful and maintain sterility.

Tie the ligature carefully several times around the condom below the knob on the plastic tubing.

Tie as tight as possible with reef knot and surgical knotting technique.

The Procedure

Clean the vulva.

Insert the lower most speculum so you can visualize the cervix.

Insert the second speculum anteriorly and place in a similar position.

Unintentional trapping of the vaginal mucosa between the two specula should be avoided, since it is very painful.

Use the long clamp to insert the tubing into the uterus.

Be careful not to grasp the condom but rather grasp the tubing.

Insert until the condom disappears into the uterus.

Fill the condom with fluids.

Start with 500 ml.

It is normal that the condom is leaking a little bit (difficult to tie the condom sufficiently tight to the tubing) – it doesn’t matter.

Continue to fill the condom until the bleeding stops.

If 500 ml is not enough, infuse more.

You can keep the infusion line open to compensate for any loss due to leaking.

Pack the upper vagina with roller gauze to prevent expulsion of the balloon.

Give Oxytocin 20 units in 1 L IV fluids (Normal Saline or Ringer's Lactate) at 60 drops per minute.

A single dose of antibiotics is recommended, for example Ampicillin 2 g IV.

Post-Procedure Care

Monitor vital signs, uterine fundal height and vaginal bleeding.

Monitor urine output every hour.

The condom can be kept inside the uterus for days if transport is needed.

Otherwise, after 6–24 hours, if there is no active vaginal bleeding, deflate the balloon.

If there is no further vaginal bleeding after 30 minutes stop the Oxytocin.

If the woman starts to bleed when the balloon is deflated, insert a new balloon and recommence the Oxytocin infusion; prepare for surgical interventions when her condition becomes stable.

Remove the urinary catheter once the woman is stable.

questions.question: What is correct regarding PPH?
questions.description:
Regarding PPH the following is correct:

It is one of the major causes of maternal death.

answers.value: It rarely affects women with a normal delivery
It is one of the major causes of maternal death
It will appear within the first 10 minutes after delivery

questions.question: Where does a post-partum bleeding most frequently originate from?
questions.description: A post-partum bleeding most frequently originate from the placental attachment site inside the uterus due to loss of tone.

answers.value: From the placental attachment site inside the uterus due to loss of tone
From a tear in the birth canal
From retained tissue

keyLearningPointDetails.description: Call for help. Then stop the bleeding.

questions.question: Prioritise the actions at strong bleeding until helpers arrive
questions.description:
At strong bleeding you should prioritise the following until helpers arrive:

1. Call for help

2. Stop the bleeding

3. Resuscitate

answers.value: Call for help
Stop the bleeding
Resuscitate

questions.question: A woman gets cold, sweaty, and feels dizzy after birth. What is the most important causes to rule out?
questions.description:
The most important causes to rule out if a woman gets cold, sweaty, and feels dizzy after birth is:

Remarkable and dangerous blood loss.
Maternal Sepsis

answers.value: Exhaustion after a long delivery
Maternal Sepsis
Low blood sugar due to stress, pain, exhaustion and lack of food
Remarkable and dangerous blood loss

questions.question: Is the amount of blood you can see the actual blood loss?
questions.description:
No, the amount of blood you can see is not the actual blood loss. 
The uterus can have a remarkable amount of blood hidden. Palpate or massage the uterus to make sure it contracts.

answers.value: Yes, the uterus will always make the blood come out of the vagina. Just keep an eye on the bleeding.
No, the uterus can have a remarkable amount of blood hidden. Palpate or massage the uterus to make sure it contracts.

questions.question: What is correct regarding moderate bleeding?
questions.description: Moderate bleeding will accumulate over time, if it is not treated.

answers.value: It is not dangerous as long as the bleeding doesn’t get excessive
It will accumulate over time, if it is not treated
It is caused by a tear in cervix
As long as vital signs are normal, wait for spontaneous recovery

keyLearningPointDetails.description: Moderate bleeding – actions: Act differently depending on the character of the bleeding

questions.question: What would you do within 15 minutes at moderate bleeding directly after birth?
questions.description:
Within 15 minutes at moderate bleeding directly after birth you should do the following:

Empty the bladder.

Apply uterus massage.

Vital signs and IV fluids.

answers.value: Empty the bladder
Apply uterus massage
Vital signs and IV fluids
Remove the placenta manually

questions.question: Why is uterine massage recommended?
questions.description:
Uterine massage is recommended because:

The wound, where the placenta used to sit, is thereby minimized and bleeding decreases.

answers.value: The wound, where the placenta used to sit, is thereby minimized and bleeding decreases
It inhibits the blood supply to a bleeding tear and the bleeding decreases
It stimulates the brain to release Oxytocin and the bleeding decreases

questions.question: Why should the bladder by emptied at PPH?
questions.description:
The main reason why emptying the bladder is indicated at PPH is:

A full bladder makes it difficult for the uterus to contract properly.

answers.value: A full bladder makes it difficult for the uterus to contract properly
It is difficult to assess the bleeding if it is mixed with running urine
A permanent urine catheter will minimize the risk of stitches in the urethra, when sewing a bleeding tear

questions.question: What is true regarding checking vital signs at strong bleeding?
questions.description:
The following is true regarding checking vital signs at strong bleeding:

It is a waste of valuable time as long as you are alone.

answers.value: It is a waste of valuable time as long as you are alone
It is the first thing to do no matter what to know the starting point
It is important – because Misoprostol must not be given to patients with pulse above 100 bpm

questions.question: At strong bleeding, why do you stop the bleeding before you resuscitate the woman?
questions.description:
At strong bleeding, you stop the bleeding before you resuscitate the woman because:

The woman can bleed to death faster than you can resuscitate.

You cannot keep the pace with IV fluids, if she is bleeding heavily and uncontrolled.

answers.value: The woman can bleed to death faster than you can resuscitate
You cannot keep the pace with IV fluids, if she is bleeding heavily and uncontrolled
Trick question! Of course, you resuscitate immediately and manage the bleeding afterwards

questions.question: What are the advantages of bimanual compression?
questions.description:
The advantages of bimanual compression are:

It provides pressure on the uterus so a bleeding due to lack of tone is controlled.

It can control the bleeding until helpers arrive.

It can reduce the bleeding from a cervical tear while the assistant prepares for suturing.

It cannot do any harm, but can on the other hand save lives.

answers.value: It provides pressure on the uterus so a bleeding due to lack of tone is controlled
It can control the bleeding until helpers arrive
It can reduce the bleeding from a cervical tear while the assistant prepares for suturing
It cannot do any harm, but can on the other hand save lives

questions.question: Bimanual compression: How do you check if the bleeding has halted?
questions.description: You remove your abdominal hand every five minutes to check whether the uterus softens and grows in size which means that it is still bleeding inside of it. Or whether it remains contracted with no signs of excessive bleeding.

answers.value: I stop the bimanual compression after half an hour and assume that the bleeding has halted
I remove my abdominal hand every five minutes to check if the bleeding has halted

questions.question: What do you do if long sterile gloves for bimanual compression are not available?
questions.description:
If long sterile gloves for bimanual compression are not available, you do the following:

Use normal sterile gloves.

Alternatively, use whatever sort of gloves available at your facility.

answers.value: Use normal sterile gloves
Alternatively, use whatever sort of gloves available at your facility
Due to high risk of infection, do not apply bimanual compression

questions.description: You give 1 g IV Tranexamic Acid that can be repeated after half an hour.

answers.value: 1 g IV - can be repeated after half an hour
0.5 g IV - can be repeated after half an hour
0.5 g IM - once
1 g IM - once

Identify trauma to the rectal sphincter.

The treatment of retained tissue is:

Manual removal of the tissue.

answers.value: Manual removal of the tissue
Surgical removal of the tissue
No treatment – the uterus rejects the tissue itself

questions.question: Removal of tissue: List the actions in correct order
questions.description:
The correct order of the actions is:

1. Insert a flat hand up into the uterus

2. Support the uterus on top of the fundus with the external hand

3. Carefully move the hand from side to side with fingers tightly together

4. Withdraw fragments and palpate cavity to ensure complete removal

Support the uterus on top of the fundus with the external hand
